docTitle.titlePart: On the electronic origin of the inverse magnetocaloric effect in Ni-Co-Mn-In Heusler alloys

front.div:
In order to understand the electronic origin of the inverse magnetocaloric effect
observed in the Ni-Co-Mn-In system we used the combination of indirect
experimental probes as magnetization, resistivity and specific heat. Findings are
compared with the band structure of isostructural Heusler alloys like Ni-Mn-Ga.
We suggest that the inverse magnetocaloric effect in Ni-Co-Mn-In originates from
the high density of states close to Fermi energy. Within the austenite state this
causes ferromagnetic band splitting. The structural change to the martensite
allows an alternative way to reduce the high density of states at lower
temperature, which does not require the band splitting and thus it does not support
ferromagnetic order.
